title: Sebastien Vahaamahina sent off for brutal elbow against Wales
text:
Vahaamahina elbowed Wainwright directly in the face (Picture: ITV)

Sebastien Vahaamahina thrust France’s entire Rugby World Cup campaign into jeopardy when he was sent off in their quarter-final clash with Wales.

His red card came with Wales trailing 19-10 but a man down, France saw that lead evaporate and they crashed out of the World Cup thanks to a 20-19 defeat.

With less than 10 minutes gone after half-time, the second-row was in the middle of a rolling maul, grappling with Welsh flanker Aaron Wainwright.

Vahaamahina grabbed him round the neck before throwing an elbow into Wainwright’s face.

RED CARD! Vahaamahina sees red after an elbow on Aaron Wainwright. Don't think there can be any complaints with that. France down to 14.#RWC2019 #ITVRugby #WALvFRA pic.twitter.com/fHTsfbwGTh — ITV Rugby (@ITVRugby) October 20, 2019

Initially, referee Jaco Peyper merely awarded a penalty for the high tackle on the advice of his assistant Nic Berry, but when the full incident appeared on the big screen, the official in charge halted the game to watch another replay.

The decision, with the help of TMO Marius Jonker, was arrived at quickly and Peyper had not doubt in his mind that it had to be a red card.

‘First around the neck and then a second go – bang,’ Peyper said during his brief deliberation.

‘It’s very clear. I’m saying that’s a red card.’

Captain Guilhem Guirado and Vahaamahina himself had few complaints about the decision as Peyper explained it to them and the dismissed man held his hand up in apology to his team-mates as he jogged off the field.

Former Wales winger Shane Williams, working on the ITV coverage of the game, was left stunned by Vahaamahina’s decision to hit Wainwright.

‘It’s the right call [from the referee],’ Williams said.

‘It’s ridiculous. What is he doing?’
description: Sebastien Vahaamahina thrust France's entire Rugby World Cup campaign into jeopardy when he was sent off in their quarter-final clash with Wales.
